definition: the right to be elected/the right to stand for election

quilt/by/(indicates passive-voice clauses)/(literary) to cover/to meet with/(coll.) (since c. 2009) used before a verb that does not accurately represent what actually happened, to describe with black humor how sb or sth was dealt with by the authorities (as in 被自殺|被自杀[bei4 zi4 sha1])
to lift/to hold up/to cite/to enumerate/to act/to raise/to choose/to elect/act/move/deed

sentences.english: Every citizen over the age of 21 has the right to be elected to the Knesset .
sentences.chinese: 所有年满21岁的公民都有议会的被选举权。

sentences.english: Article 10 . Women shall enjoy the equal right, with men, to vote and to stand for election.
sentences.chinese: 第十条妇女享有与男子平等的选举权和被选举权。

sentences.english: Rights of people with the right to be elected and candidates as well are of unique constitutional value.
sentences.chinese: 其中，被选举权人和候选人的权利有独特的宪法价值。

sentences.english: Every citizen has a right to vote and to be voted.
sentences.chinese: 每个公民都有选举权和被选举权。

sentences.english: In New China, women have the right to elect and to be elected on equal terms with men.
sentences.chinese: 在新中国，妇女有同男子平等的选举权和被选举权。

sentences.english: The criminal was deprived of the right to be elected.
sentences.chinese: 那个罪犯的被选举权被剥夺了。

sentences.english: The citizens aged 18 have vote and elected right.
sentences.chinese: 年满十八岁公民，都有选举权和被选举权。

definition: right (i.e. an entitlement to sth)/(classical) power and wealth
